subject: Art & Design
title: Understanding White Balance: Why Colors Shift
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Understanding White Balance: Why Colors Shift.

hook.text: Indoor photos look orange. Shade photos look blue. Your eyes auto-correct. Your camera doesn't.

buildup.text: White balance adjusts how the camera interprets color temperature â€” measured in Kelvin.

discovery.text: Daylight is ~5500K (neutral). Tungsten bulbs are ~3200K (warm). Shade is ~7000K (cool blue).

twist.text: Auto white balance works 80% of the time. The other 20% â€” mixed lighting, creative intent â€” requires manual control.

climax.text: Shooting RAW lets you change white balance later without quality loss. It's the safety net of color.

punchline.text: The 'wrong' white balance can be the right creative choice.

quiz.question: Why do indoor photos often look orange?
options: Tungsten bulbs emit warm light around 3200K that the camera captures
Cameras add orange filters indoors automatically
Indoor air particles scatter orange light
